title: Consumer Cos Down Amid Recession Fears — Consumer Roundup
text:
Shares of retailers and other consumer-services companies fell amid fears that the U.S. was sliding toward a recession.

For the second month in a row, the Institute for Supply Management's survey of manufacturers indicated factory activity was slowing.

Recent consumer data has held up much better than the factory data but some economists question whether this is sustainable. "My expectation is that the weakness in this sector will, if unchecked, spread into other sectors as well, as it typically does," said Eric Winograd, senior economist at money manager AllianceBernstein.

More than 2,500 U.S. companies had asked the Trump administration to make exceptions for about 31,000 products, including auto parts and frozen fish, as of midnight Monday, the deadline for filing requests to be exempted from the $200 billion tranche of tariffs that the U.S. implemented last year on items imported from China.

Japanese car companies such as Toyota Motor, Nissan Motor and Honda Motor all posted double-digit-percentage sales declines in September from a year earlier, as fewer selling days.

McCormick & Co. posted higher quarterly profit as demand for products such as Frank's RedHot sauce and French's mustard boosted the spice maker's sales.
